message.content:
We must “re‐build” the COGS from the sale side by “tracing” all inventory‑related lines and using each product’s cost per unit (set from its purchase records). In our case the only products that are “sold” are Chemical Product A, Chemical Product C, Chemical Product D and Chemical Product B. (The “Initial” and “Fixed Assets” and “Expense” etc. entries do not affect inventory cost.) 

To explain briefly, we first “gather” for each product the purchase cost (we assume that each purchase for a given product had a fixed cost‑per‑unit, so when an item later sells the cost is its purchase unit cost) and then, for every “Sale” line, we compute the cost portion as (sold quantity × cost per unit).

The data give us (note that cost per unit is explicitly provided in purchase rows):

• For Chemical Product A (product P001)
  – Purchases (all at 10,000 per unit):
  • Purchase20231231001: 19 units at 10,000 each
  • Purchase20231231011: 10 units at 10,000 each 
  • Purchase20231231012: 21 units at 10,000 each  
  Total available = 19 + 10 + 21 = 50 units
  – Sales of product P001 (we add sold quantities):
  • Sale20240104008: 3 units
  • Sale20240108017: 4 units
  • Sale20240112027: 1 unit
  • Sale20240115033: 4 units
  • Sale20240116034: 5 units
  • Sale20240117036: 5 units
  • Sale20240129054: 3 units  
  Total sold = 3+4+1+4+5+5+3 = 25 units
  – Thus, cost component = 25 × 10,000 = 250,000

• For Chemical Product C (product P003)
  – Purchases (all at 50,000 per unit):
  • Purchase20231231002: 16 units (16 × 50,000 = 800,000)
  • Purchase20231231003: 9 units         (9 × 50,000 = 450,000)
  • Purchase20231231004: 15 units       (15 × 50,000 = 750,000)
  • Purchase20231231010: 25 units       (25 × 50,000 = 1,250,000)
  • Purchase20231231015: 26 units       (26 × 50,000 = 1,300,000)
  Total purchased = 16 + 9 + 15 + 25 + 26 = 91 units
  – Sales for P003 (summing sold quantities from each sale line):
  • Sale20240102003: 4 units
  • Sale20240103005: 1 unit
  • Sale20240103006: 2 units
  • Sale20240104007: 5 units
  • Sale20240107016: 3 units
  • Sale20240109019: 3 units
  • Sale20240111024: 4 units
  • Sale20240112028: 2 units
  • Sale20240114031: 3 units
  • Sale20240115032: 4 units
  • Sale20240116035: 2 units
  • Sale20240126053: 3 units
  • Sale20240119042: 2 units
  • Sale20240120044: 4 units
  • Sale20240123049: 1 unit
  • Sale20240124050: 4 units
  • Sale20240130056: 2 units
  • Sale20240129055: 4 units  
  Total sold = 4+1+2+5+3+3+4+2+3+4+2+3+2+4+1+4+2+4 = 53 units   (you can check that 4+1=5, 5+2=7, +5=12, +3=15, +3=18, +4=22, +2=24, +3=27, +4=31, +2=33, +3=36, +2=38, +4=42, +1=43, +4=47, +2=49, +4=53)
  – Thus, cost component = 53 × 50,000 = 2,650,000

• For Chemical Product D (product P004)
  – Purchases:
  • Purchase20231231005: 16 units at 100,000 each (1,600,000)
  • Purchase20231231009: 27 units at 100,000 each (2,700,000)
  • Purchase20231231013: 8 units at 100,000 each   (800,000)
  Total = 16 + 27 + 8 = 51 units
  – Sales of P004:
  • Sale20240106011: 2 units
  • Sale20240106012: 4 units
  • Sale20240108018: 5 units
  • Sale20240111025: 5 units
  • Sale20240119043: 4 units
  • Sale20240121045: 1 unit
  • Sale20240122047: 3 units
  • Sale20240123048: 5 units
  • Sale20240128057: 5 units  
  Total sold = 2+4+5+5+4+1+3+5+5 = 34 units
  – Thus, cost component = 34 × 100,000 = 3,400,000

• For Chemical Product B (product P002)
  – Purchases:
  • Purchase20231231008: 15 units at 20,000 each (300,000)
  • Purchase20231231014: 20 units at 20,000 each (400,000)
  Total = 35 units
  – Sales of P002:
  • Sale20240107015: 4 units
  • Sale20240109020: 3 units
  • Sale20240110021: 2 units
  • Sale20240113029: 2 units
  • Sale20240118038: 2 units
  • Sale20240118039: 5 units
  • Sale20240121046: 3 units
  • Sale20240130057: 3 units  
  Total sold = 4+3+2+2+2+5+3+3 = 22 units
  – Thus, cost component = 22 × 20,000 = 440,000

Finally, the overall cost of goods sold comes from adding the cost portions from all products:
  P001: 250,000 
  P003: 2,650,000 
  P004: 3,400,000 
  P002: 440,000 
Sum = 250,000 + 2,650,000 = 2,900,000; 
  2,900,000 + 3,400,000 = 6,300,000; 
  6,300,000 + 440,000 = 6,740,000

Therefore, the final Cost of Goods Sold is 6,740,000.00.

We now present the solution in the requested JSON format.

Final answer:

{
  "solution": {
    "Cost of Goods Sold": "6740000.00"
  }
}
